message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The acute onset of pain and limp suggest transient synovitis, and the ultrasound finding of increased joint fluid supports the diagnosis. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis usually occurs in adolescents and is characterized by gradual onset of hip pain with a limited range of motion. Legg-Calve-Perthes disease is also a gradual onset and is more common in boys aged 4-10. Developmental dysplasia of the hip is typically diagnosed in infancy or early childhood and is associated with an abnormal hip joint.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of a sudden onset of hip pain and limping with no previous trauma, as well as the presence of increased fluid in the joint on ultrasound, are suggestive of transient synovitis. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis, Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, and developmental dysplasia of the hip may cause similar symptoms but are less likely given the patient's age, exam findings, and imaging results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fever, inability to walk, and abnormal gait suggest that the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms is transient synovitis. The slightly abducted and externally rotated hip supports this diagnosis. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is more common in adolescents, and Legg-Calve-Perthes disease usually presents with painless limp. Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in infancy. The increased fluid within the joint seen on ultrasound is also consistent with transient synovitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a hip joint problem, and the ultrasound shows increased fluid within the joint, which is most consistent with transient synovitis. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis and Legg-Calve-Perthes disease are more likely to have abnormalities on X-ray. Developmental dysplasia of the hip is less likely given the normal hip exam.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including recent mild illness and increased fluid within the joint, suggest transient synovitis. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis often presents with the inability to bear weight, and Legg-Calve-Perthes disease and developmental dysplasia of the hip have characteristic findings on X-ray, which are not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of recent viral illness and presents with hip pain and limping. Increased fluid within the joint indicates inflammation. These findings are consistent with transient synovitis. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis may cause hip pain and limp, but it typically presents with restricted hip flexion, not external rotation like in this case. Legg-Calve-Perthes disease typically presents with a slowly progressive limp and restricted hip abduction and internal rotation. Developmental dysplasia of the hip usually presents in infancy or early childhood and causes hip instability and limited hip abduction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy’s symptoms suggest Transient synovitis, which is the most common cause of acute hip pain in children. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis, Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, and Developmental dysplasia of the hip can cause similar symptoms, but these conditions are typically ruled out by diagnostic imaging. The presence of increased fluid in the joint on ultrasound supports the diagnosis of Transient synovitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with transient synovitis, which is the most common cause of hip pain in children. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis would typically present with limited internal rotation, and Legg-Calve-Perthes disease and developmental dysplasia of the hip would show abnormalities on X-ray. The increased fluid within the joint on ultrasound supports the diagnosis of transient synovitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with transient synovitis, which is the most common hip disorder in children aged 3-10 years. It typically presents with sudden onset of hip pain accompanied by a limp and sometimes low-grade fever. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis and Legg-Calve-Perthes disease may cause similar symptoms but are less likely in this age group. Developmental dysplasia of the hip is a congenital condition and is typically diagnosed earlier in life. Ultrasound shows increased fluid within the joint, supporting the diagnosis of transient synovitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest transient synovitis, which is a common cause of acute hip pain in children. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis may cause similar symptoms but is more common in older children. Legg-Calve-Perthes disease and developmental dysplasia of the hip are less likely given the patient’s age and lack of significant physical findings on examination and imaging.
